There are seven dharmas for disciples of the Way, who are at ease and joyful in the present world, and who practice diligently to attain the end of the Dharma.
What are the seven dharmas?
First, knowing the Dharma; second, knowing the meaning; third, knowing the time; fourth, knowing moderation; fifth, knowing oneself; sixth, knowing the assembly; seventh, knowing people.

What is meant by knowing the Dharma?
It means being able to understand the twelve divisions of the canon:

The first is prose, the second is song, the third is discourse, the fourth is verse, the fifth is parable, the sixth is biography, the seventh is explanation, the eighth is biography, the ninth is extensive, the tenth is spontaneous, the eleventh is practice, and the twelfth is chapter and verse. This is knowing the Dharma.
Not understanding the twelve divisions of the scriptures is not knowing the Dharma.
What is meant by knowing the meaning?
Understanding the meaning of the scriptures and teachings spoken by each is knowing the meaning.
Not understanding and not knowing what is spoken by each is not knowing the meaning.
What is meant by knowing the time?

Knowing when it is appropriate to contemplate the thought of quiescent extinction, when it is not appropriate to contemplate the thought of receiving and practicing, and when it is appropriate to contemplate the thought of careful protection, this is knowing the time.
Not understanding the appropriate conduct at different times is not knowing the time.
What is meant by knowing moderation?

One can eat and drink little, defecate and urinate little, and one's digestion becomes smooth. One can control one's coming and going, sitting and rising, walking, lying down, waking up, speaking, and silence. One's affairs become simple and frugal. This is called knowing moderation.
Not being able to control oneself is called not knowing moderation.
What is meant by knowing oneself?

Knowing one's own mind, whether it is old or young, what one believes in, what precepts one observes, what one has heard, what one gives, what wisdom one has, what one understands, what one has attained, and what one has entered, knowing the depth and shallowness, the thickness and thinness of each matter, is called knowing oneself.
Not knowing the depth and shallowness of one's own mind and what one has entered is called not knowing oneself.

Not knowing what is appropriate for the time in that assembly is called not knowing the assembly.
What is meant by knowing people?

It is like two people, one who has faith in the Way and one who does not have faith in the Way. The one who has faith in the Way can be praised, the one who does not have faith in the Way cannot be praised.
Having faith in the Way has two groups:
One person often visits the place of practice and enjoys being an ascetic, one person does not often visit the place of practice but has the strategy of an ascetic.
The one who often visits can be praised, the one who does not often visit cannot be praised.
Often visiting the place of practice has two groups:
One person loves and respects ascetics, one person does not love and respect ascetics.
The one who loves and respects can be praised, the one who does not love and respect cannot be praised.
Loving and respecting has two groups:
One person closely associates with ascetics, one person does not closely associate with ascetics.
The one who closely associates can be praised, the one who does not closely associate cannot be praised.

The one who likes to ask can be praised, the one who does not like to ask cannot be praised.
There are two kinds of people who like to ask questions:
One listens with ears cocked, the other does not listen with ears cocked.
Those who listen with ears cocked are praiseworthy, those who do not listen with ears cocked are not praiseworthy.
Those who listen with ears cocked are of two kinds:
One hears the Dharma and upholds it, the other hears the Dharma but does not uphold it.
Those who hear the Dharma and uphold it are praiseworthy, those who do not uphold it are not praiseworthy.
Those who uphold it are of two kinds:
One hears and contemplates the meaning, the other hears but does not contemplate the meaning.
Those who hear and contemplate the meaning are praiseworthy, those who hear but do not contemplate the meaning are not praiseworthy.
Those who hear the Dharma and contemplate the meaning are of two kinds:

One understands the meaning of the sutras as they are, and establishes the Dharma according to the Dharma, the other does not understand the meaning of the sutras as they are, and does not establish the Dharma according to the Dharma.
Those who understand the meaning of the sutras as they are are praiseworthy, those who do not understand the meaning of the sutras as they are are not praiseworthy.
Those who understand the meaning of the sutras as they are are of two kinds:

One person only seeks to secure themselves, not others, not many people, not out of compassion for the world, not for the benefit of the world. Another person is able to secure themselves, and also others, many people, the world, out of compassion, for the benefit of the world.

Monks, you should know the difference between one who seeks to secure themselves, and one who is able to secure others, many people, the world, out of compassion, for the benefit of the world. This person is the highest, the longest, the most venerable, the most supreme.
It is like milk becoming curd, curd becoming butter, butter becoming ghee, ghee being the best.
Such a person is the best among people, the one with the highest practice, the most venerable practice, the most supreme practice, the most victorious, the highest aspiration, the unsurpassed.
Monks!
Being able to see two people as wise and noble, being able to distinguish this person as good, this person as superior, this is knowing people.
After the Buddha said this, they all joyfully accepted it.
